an
Problem pages, ibration therapy again
Last month you guys took a good look at a page which was subsequently deleted: Cycloidal vibration therapy, particularly ing|user:RexxS who looked at all the citations for MEDRS. Unfortunately there looks like a whole industry of pages out there usually being edited by the same editors, and I would appreciate if someone has the time to look at these two: alileo (vibration training) (incidentally one of the editor's IP (217.92.49.4) is novotecmedical.de which you can probably guess what they make). And hole body vibration which is again being edited by a bunch of single issue editors, like Samvesey, Rrawer, Belsius (to whom ing|user:DGG has kindly given a final warning) and that same IP editor from the Galileo page. seems to me they could all be the same editor, or working as a team but i've no idea how you would find that out without looking into their accounts. I expect if you look through their edit histories there are more pages like this. Anyway, I appreciate it's a drag but if someone can look at these and check i'm not being paranoid, and see if these pages are giant adverts again, hopefully get rid of them, I would really appreciate your help. As an aside can you let me know if it's ok to bring things here to be checked for MEDRS or is there an piece of software I can use to save you having to check that aspect? I have no medical background although I have a BSc degree. Many thanks ser:Mramoeba|Mramoeba (ser talk:Mramoeba|talk) 16:19, 2 March 2017 (UTC)
Thanks for following up on this. I'm going to guess that there's some demand for an article about the idea of vibration as a weight-loss or exercise tool. Sometimes, creating a half-decent article reduces spam. It could start with the [http://www.sciencemuseum.org.uk/broughttolife/objects/display?id=92808 Battle Creek Health Builder], which seems to be the original model, and progress up to the modern versions. What do you all think? ser:WhatamIdoing|WhatamIdoing (ser talk:WhatamIdoing|talk) 02:22, 3 March 2017 (UTC) Agree would be good to merge to one good overview article. ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk ¬∑ pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs ¬∑ pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 04:16, 3 March 2017 (UTC) Pretty sure there is research out there that shows it doesn't work. I'll see if I can find anything that we can base a broad scope article off. ser:CFCF|Carl Fredrikser talk:CFCF| üíå pecial:EmailUser/CFCF|üìß 02:27, 4 March 2017 (UTC) Really? I've found a systematic review on a possible utility of whole body vibration with cerebral palsy through the PubMed search template: ite journal|last1=Saquetto|first1=M|last2=Carvalho|first2=V|last3=Silva|first3=C|last4=Concei√ß√£o|first4=C|last5=Gomes-Neto|first5=M|title=The effects of whole body vibration on mobility and balance in children with cerebral palsy: a systematic review with meta-analysis.|journal=Journal of musculoskeletal & neuronal interactions|date=June 2015|volume=15|issue=2|pages=137‚Äì144|pmc=5133716|pmid=26032205 --pecial:Contributions/122.108.141.214|122.108.141.214 (ser talk:122.108.141.214|talk) 01:26, 5 March 2017 (UTC) impact factor?--ser:Ozzie10aaaa|Ozzie10aaaa (ser talk:Ozzie10aaaa|talk) 02:18, 5 March 2017 (UTC) [http://www.ismni.org/jmni/ 1.60], despite being open access. :/ --pecial:Contributions/122.108.141.214|122.108.141.214 (ser talk:122.108.141.214|talk) 02:27, 5 March 2017 (UTC) We have a Cochrane review here[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/22336858]. Lots of sources so definitely enough for an article. ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk ¬∑ pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs ¬∑ pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 14:35, 5 March 2017 (UTC) Efficacy depends upon the condition. It could be effective for certain sub-types of CP without being effective for (e.g.,) weight loss or frailty syndrome. A well-written article will point out both the nonsense ("Buy this belly-vibrating machine to lose weight without diet or exercise! Only $39.95 if you act now!") and the sense. Is everyone okay with ibration therapy for the main article name? ser:WhatamIdoing|WhatamIdoing (ser talk:WhatamIdoing|talk) 20:34, 5 March 2017 (UTC) Or more likely, more effective for those at more severe MFCS levels (who are also more likely to have bone density issues) than those at milder levels - although the article doesn't say much about the variance in CP. I've currently got WBV in the optimistic 'other' section of the P management article, rather than the 'alt med' section. :/ --pecial:Contributions/122.108.141.214|122.108.141.214 (ser talk:122.108.141.214|talk) 20:45, 5 March 2017 (UTC) Am happy with vibration therapy as the main article. ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk ¬∑ pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs ¬∑ pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 03:29, 6 March 2017 (UTC) Thanks this is obviously now with people who know what they are talking about ser:Mramoeba|Mramoeba (ser talk:Mramoeba|talk) 19:09, 12 March 2017 (UTC)
Autoinflammatory syndrome
utoinflammatory syndrome redirects to eriodic fever syndrome. Is that right? I'm mostly wondering whether people might confuse "Autoinflammatory" with "Autoimmune". ser:WhatamIdoing|WhatamIdoing (ser talk:WhatamIdoing|talk) 20:49, 12 March 2017 (UTC) [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2948378/](more general[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4489412/]--ser:Ozzie10aaaa|Ozzie10aaaa (ser talk:Ozzie10aaaa|talk) 22:22, 12 March 2017 (UTC)
P:UNDUE at nterior cruciate ligament? ile:Knee diagram.svg|thumb|Knee diagram/Anterior cruciate ligament(left side) In amongst some useful information there is a lot of what looks like rubbish being inserted by what appears to be a P:SPA.
"Arthrometry is considered the most reliable technique of laximetry. The medical devices using arthrometry are called arthrometers and are used to put the Anterior Cruciate Ligament under stress in a controlled manner (this was not always the case as the first arthrometers required the user to use his own strength to run the tests). Over time, tests progressively evolved from static tests (single force applied on the tibia) to dynamic tests which are now considered much more precise (several forces applied on the tibia). The reason to this change is that dynamic tests allows the drawing of the ACL's stiffness curve which is a biomechanical parameter of knee ligaments. It is highly correlated with the clinical symptoms of instability. It is more accurate than laxity which is a numerical value without mechanical significance.ite journal|last=Rohman|first=Eric M.|last2=Macalena|first2=Jeffrey A.|date=2016-03-16|title=Anterior cruciate ligament assessment using arthrometry and stress imaging|url=http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4896874/|journal=Current Reviews in Musculoskeletal Medicine|volume=9|issue=2|pages=130‚Äì138|doi=10.1007/s12178-016-9331-1|issn=1935-973X|pmc=4896874|pmid=26984335"
Perhaps this is cutting edge but this is not something I have ever heard of. Seeking some advice from other editors. Is this cutting edge or P:UNDUE to be placed on nterior cruciate ligament? The pseudoscience gobbledegook and palindromic tautologous structure are what worry me most ("which is a biomechanical parameter of knee ligaments. It is highly correlated with the clinical symptoms of instability") Thoughts? --ser:LT910001|Tom (LT) (ser talk:LT910001|talk) 11:33, 1 March 2017 (UTC)
Perhaps a more general form of your question is, "Is cutting edge UNDUE?" (assuming that it's actually cutting edge, which is something that someone else will have to comment on). I think that the answer might be that it depends upon context ‚Äì what else is in the article and where it's placed. I don't might the effort to explain things in plain English. But overall, I think it needs some copyediting. For example, I'd change the bit about "this was not always the case" to a plain statement of fact about the contrast between different device models over time: "Early arthrometers were mechanical devices operated by a person's own strength; some newer ones are electrical" (or whatever the actual facts boil down to). Is that a helpful approach to the more stylistic part of your question? ser:WhatamIdoing|WhatamIdoing (ser talk:WhatamIdoing|talk) 20:23, 1 March 2017 (UTC) It does sound quite a lot like an advertisement. From my own experience laximetry is not common at all, and the being absolutely accurate (or even reliable ) isn't than important. Whether a knee is operated on depends on a number of factors, of which the exact degree of laxity seems arbitrary and of minor importance. The degree of symptoms and their severity seem far more relevant, especially considering the newer meta-analyses which show how ACL-reconstruction is no more effective than placebo. Now this is off the top of my head, and I could have something mixed up, but it seems like a good idea to check who wrote this and look into whether it actually belongs. ser:CFCF|Carl Fredrikser talk:CFCF| üíå pecial:EmailUser/CFCF|üìß 23:19, 1 March 2017 (UTC) They are trying to add the same content across 4 articles. Belongs some at ACL injury but not everywhere else.ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk ¬∑ pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs ¬∑ pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 04:23, 3 March 2017 (UTC)
*nterior cruciate ligament#Clinical significance needs editor help(edits),thank you--ser:Ozzie10aaaa|Ozzie10aaaa (ser talk:Ozzie10aaaa|talk) 09:36, 13 March 2017 (UTC)
Wikimania Only two more weeks to submit talks for the main event. ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk ¬∑ pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs ¬∑ pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 02:03, 13 March 2017 (UTC)
*[https://wikimania2017.wikimedia.org/wiki/Submissions]--ser:Ozzie10aaaa|Ozzie10aaaa (ser talk:Ozzie10aaaa|talk) 11:20, 14 March 2017 (UTC)
New Google feature
Interesting: [https://theconversation.com/dr-google-probably-isnt-the-worst-place-to-get-your-health-advice-73835 Dr Google probably isn‚Äôt the worst place to get your health advice] - apparently now Google will be employing doctors to provide short glosses for health-related searches. I wonder what kind of impact this will have on people accessing Wikipedia's health information? --pecial:Contributions/122.108.141.214|122.108.141.214 (ser talk:122.108.141.214|talk) 00:08, 14 March 2017 (UTC) Actually much of their information is pretty horrible, and the composition is very opaque: does not show sources, does not take into account any COI, and often does not give an accurate or full picture. Anyone can partner with doctors, without systematic methodology that does not mean any good will come out of it. The fact that this implies they have been writing medical information without the input of doctors before is rather scary. ser:CFCF|Carl Fredrikser talk:CFCF| üíå pecial:EmailUser/CFCF|üìß 10:40, 14 March 2017 (UTC) Thanks IP. This launched more than a year ago in the USA. Google just linked to health information before. They are now actively creating health information in house. They have some really nice illustrations. They have corrected their hep C entry since the launch following feedback. (used to say sexually transmitted which it likely isn't) Google says 5% of all searches are for health information. They are partnered with Mayo on this and do reference them as a source sometimes. Competition in "health information" is increasing. ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk ¬∑ pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs ¬∑ pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 16:26, 14 March 2017 (UTC)
MAP and CD
Ignoring the cite error, I can't help but feel that recent good faith edits to this ycobacterium avium subspecies paratuberculosis|MAP article are confusing, the lead says that MAP is a causal agent in CD. However I read [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4177485/ this] paper which surmises ‚ÄúThe present data do not demonstrate that MAP is the causal agent in CD, however, a certain degree of involvement of this bacterium in the physiopathological steps of the disease is reasonable.‚Äù Is there a more recent review article relating to this? ser:CV9933|CV9933 (ser talk:CV9933|talk) 20:52, 15 March 2017 (UTC) Pretty certain that this question ain't settled yet. Needs also better spelling/grammar. ser:Jo-Jo Eumerus|Jo-Jo Eumerus (ser talk:Jo-Jo Eumerus|talk, pecial:CentralAuth/Jo-Jo Eumerus|contributions) 21:39, 15 March 2017 (UTC)
heumatoid arthritis
More eyes needed, thanks. See alk:Rheumatoid_arthritis#Additions -- ser:Jytdog|Jytdog (ser talk:Jytdog|talk) 17:55, 15 March 2017 (UTC) [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Rheumatoid_arthritis&diff=770479460&oldid=770479236]...as soon as it expires, the article will need many references[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28285723]--ser:Ozzie10aaaa|Ozzie10aaaa (ser talk:Ozzie10aaaa|talk) 22:45, 15 March 2017 (UTC)
Clean up Have been cleaning up some of the links to the dailymail. Many of the articles that use the DM as a source are paid for spam or click bait.
Anyway know how to search only articles within a particular Wikiproject for a url? ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk ¬∑ pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs ¬∑ pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 16:29, 12 March 2017 (UTC) Think I found it elp:Advanced_search#Parameters ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk ¬∑ pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs ¬∑ pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 16:45, 12 March 2017 (UTC) Doesn't that only search categories? ser:CFCF|Carl Fredrikser talk:CFCF| üíå pecial:EmailUser/CFCF|üìß 16:54, 12 March 2017 (UTC) It search for "text" within all articles within a category. But the problem is it does not search for "urls". Hum... ser:Keilana you managed to do this did you not? ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk ¬∑ pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs ¬∑ pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 17:13, 12 March 2017 (UTC) Okay found the issue. The Wikiproject Medicine categories are on the talk page not the content page. We have GA tags on the article page. So [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?search=incategory%3AGood_articles+insource%3A+%22ref+http%3A%2F%2Fwww.dailymail.co.uk%22&title=Special:Search&profile=all&fulltext=1&searchToken=20txi9o1bbo9yagoc992b8qni] gives you all the GAs were DM is used. ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk ¬∑ pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs ¬∑ pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 17:41, 12 March 2017 (UTC) This will search all articles that contain "Infobox medical condition" for a specific url[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?search=hastemplate%3AInfobox_medical_condition+insource%3A+%22ref+http%3A%2F%2Fwww.dailymail.co.uk%22&title=Special:Search&profile=all&fulltext=1&searchToken=3jifzzhsq3v6gietwvleoi494]. So part of the way there. ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk ¬∑ pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs ¬∑ pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 18:02, 12 March 2017 (UTC) very useful[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?search=hastemplate%3AInfobox_medical_condition+insource%3A+%22ref+http%3A%2F%2Fwww.dailymail.co.uk%22&title=Special:Search&profile=all&fulltext=1&searchToken=2dlexk25catkz2ra43r0bx5a2]--ser:Ozzie10aaaa|Ozzie10aaaa (ser talk:Ozzie10aaaa|talk) 18:39, 12 March 2017 (UTC) ref doesn't work, so just search for [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?search=hastemplate%3AInfobox_medical_condition+insource%3A+%22dailymail.co.uk%22&title=Special:Search&profile=all&fulltext=1&searchToken=4aagpquzt3h07k8dgaqyo5gs7 hastemplate:Infobox_medical_condition insource: "dailymail.co.uk"] Lots of trimming to be done... ser:CFCF|Carl Fredrikser talk:CFCF| üíå pecial:EmailUser/CFCF|üìß 10:19, 13 March 2017 (UTC) Ah great link. Thanks ser:CFCF. Done. Likely we will need to do regular checks. Any idea how to search all articles within P:MED? ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk ¬∑ pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs ¬∑ pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 18:26, 13 March 2017 (UTC) |MastCell has done this before (ser:MastCell/Daily_Mail_links). ser:Adrian J. Hunter|Adrian¬†J.¬†Hunter(ser talk:Adrian J. Hunter|talk‚Ä¢pecial:contributions/Adrian J. Hunter|contribs) 10:18, 14 March 2017 (UTC) Okay hopefully ser:MastCell will explain how he did it. ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk ¬∑ pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs ¬∑ pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 00:58, 15 March 2017 (UTC) Thanks. This is helpful information for searching for references. ser:JenOttawa|JenOttawa (ser talk:JenOttawa|talk) 02:08, 16 March 2017 (UTC)
RISPR [https://www.newscientist.com/article/2123973-first-results-of-crispr-gene-editing-of-normal-embryos-released/ may be good to add to above article or related article(Gene therapy)]....[https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs00438-017-1299-z]--ser:Ozzie10aaaa|Ozzie10aaaa (ser talk:Ozzie10aaaa|talk) 23:13, 16 March 2017 (UTC)

Thanks.

Primary vitrectomy without gas tamponade|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00417-016-3302-5|journal=Graefe's Archive for Clinical and Experimental Ophthalmology|language=en|volume=254|issue=4|pages=689‚Äì689|doi=10.1007/s00417-016-3302-5|issn=0721-832X|pmid=26916780
I'll park the ref here in case the edit history gets deleted. That was [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Retinal_detachment&diff=next&oldid=770606924 bad news]. ser:QuackGuru|QuackGuru (ser talk:QuackGuru|talk) 22:01, 16 March 2017 (UTC) Interesting. DMOZ is dead
MOZ was turned off today. The l|dmoz template has been redirected to a mirror as a temporary measure. P:MEDMOS needs to be updated to remove any mention of the site, and it would probably be appropriate to remove links/templates from articles as you run across them. ser:WhatamIdoing|WhatamIdoing (ser talk:WhatamIdoing|talk) 05:43, 15 March 2017 (UTC) Not so quick. All of DMOZ is mirrored by internet archives. We can just change the template to link to internet archives instead. Maybe someone else will take up the project. It is under a CC BY license. ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk ¬∑ pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs ¬∑ pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 06:02, 15 March 2017 (UTC) Discussion is taking place here emplate talk:Dmoz I tried to get DMOZ to join us as a WMF site a few years back. The community was basically non existent back than :-( Likely why they shut it down. ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk ¬∑ pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs ¬∑ pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 06:10, 15 March 2017 (UTC) Was the WMF interested in taking them aboard? ser:CFCF|Carl Fredrikser talk:CFCF| üíå pecial:EmailUser/CFCF|üìß 09:42, 15 March 2017 (UTC) In my experience, the DMOZ pages have not been very good in recent years. I just spot-checked a few: half have seen no updates during the last year. On the one about autism, which was allegedly updated just a few weeks ago, one of the NIH links is broken, the most recent news story is from 2006, one goes to a dead internet forum (most recent post from July 2016), and one of the links is filled with ads for "natural viagra". I don't think that's really helping readers, and I'm pretty sure that we could find a better option. All of DMOZ is mirrored by several sites (including the one that the template has been redirected to), but I don't think that a link to a copy of a page that was last updated a year or two ago by a DMOZ volunteer is going to continue to have value for readers in the long-run. Websites get re-arranged. Links die. Information goes out of date. And even if you think a DMOZ mirror or an archived copy of DMOZ pages is a good way to ward off spam here, MEDMOS shouldn't say that DMOZ itself exists, because that is false. ser:WhatamIdoing|WhatamIdoing (ser talk:WhatamIdoing|talk) 22:20, 15 March 2017 (UTC) They still do a better job than we typically do. ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk ¬∑ pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs ¬∑ pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 00:14, 17 March 2017 (UTC)
Stipulating what type of article a journal article is Am working on a research study. The question is of references that are journal article (ie. use the cite journal template) what portion are "review articles" and what portion are not. We have a parameter "|type=" for cite journal where this data goes. I would like propose adding it by bot to cite journal templates in GAs and FAs. Others thoughts? ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk ¬∑ pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs ¬∑ pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 17:52, 6 March 2017 (UTC)
Support *--ser:Ozzie10aaaa|Ozzie10aaaa (ser talk:Ozzie10aaaa|talk) 17:59, 6 March 2017 (UTC)--ser:Ozzie10aaaa|Ozzie10aaaa (ser talk:Ozzie10aaaa|talk) 17:59, 6 March 2017 (UTC)
Oppose
Discussion What's stopping us from populating all WP:MED-tagged articles with this? What do you think |Harej, I know you've been working a lot with similar issues. ser:CFCF|Carl Fredrikser talk:CFCF| üíå pecial:EmailUser/CFCF|üìß 18:01, 6 March 2017 (UTC) Yes once the bot is created would be easy to do it for all articles in the WPMED area. For those that do not use the "cite journal" template it would not be as useful. ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk ¬∑ pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs ¬∑ pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 18:15, 6 March 2017 (UTC) Why not just request |Smith609, the manager of [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/User:Citation_bot Citation bot], to add it? --ser:Zefr|Zefr (ser talk:Zefr|talk) 18:26, 6 March 2017 (UTC) utdent This proposal is somewhat controversial (see this previous [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help_talk:Citation_Style_1/Archive_7#Cite_journal_-_review_article_vs._non-review discussion]). I was in favor, but other argued that classifying primary vs. secondary citations amounted to original research. Also ara|type refers to the media type and therefore is probably not appropriate. ara|deparment is probably more appropriate. ser:Boghog|Boghog (ser talk:Boghog|talk) 20:11, 6 March 2017 (UTC) I assume this is meant primarily for medical articles, in which most citations already have PMIDs. You could just extract the PMIDs and use the PubMed API to retrieve the data for your study ([https://eutils.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/eutils/esummary.fcgi?db=pubmed&id=11850928,11482001&retmode=json example query], though you'd probably want to use the Entrez History feature for large sets), without the need to make any actual edits or store the data on-wiki. ser:Opabinia regalis|Opabinia regalis (ser talk:Opabinia regalis|talk) 21:19, 6 March 2017 (UTC) |Boghog ‚Äî that's just crazy. It would be automated, using the data that exists in a database already. It objectively isn't P:OR. If that was the basis of the consensus we can just overturn it here by stating that it was wrong. ser:CFCF|Carl Fredrikser talk:CFCF| üíå pecial:EmailUser/CFCF|üìß 23:37, 6 March 2017 (UTC) As far as I can tell, there wasn't a real consensus developed in the previous discussion. To completely remove the OR issue, a new ara|pubmed-type parameter in l|cite journal may be needed. If one extracts the PubMed [http://www.nlm.nih.gov/mesh/pubtypes.html Publication Type] for each citation and uses those directly without modification, then it is not OR. Translating PubMed Publication Types into primary (clinical trial) or secondary (review/meta-analysis/monograph) may be OR. ser:Boghog|Boghog (ser talk:Boghog|talk) 04:58, 7 March 2017 (UTC)
One of the main concerns I have with putting the 'review' field on l|cite journal is that the template is used for many other disciplines' articles, so it might confuse them. Is there a ARC standards|MARC field for "Review", "Original Research", "Case Study" etc.? What do they call that field? --pecial:Contributions/122.108.141.214|122.108.141.214 (ser talk:122.108.141.214|talk) 05:49, 7 March 2017 (UTC) Would not be original research. We would be using pubmed as a source. Pubmed calls it "publication type" and the type we would be recording is "review" which is what they call it. Happy to go with "|pubmed-type=" as boghog suggests. ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk ¬∑ pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs ¬∑ pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 06:34, 7 March 2017 (UTC) "|pubmed-type=" would be fine--ser:Ozzie10aaaa|Ozzie10aaaa (ser talk:Ozzie10aaaa|talk) 10:45, 17 March 2017 (UTC) I meant "Original Research" as an alternative I've seen to review articles, and case studies - I thought I'd seen it in ScienceDirect when I've been doing exploratory searches. --pecial:Contributions/122.108.141.214|122.108.141.214 (ser talk:122.108.141.214|talk) 08:02, 7 March 2017 (UTC)
It would appear that MARC standards apply to books and serials (journals and magazines), not individual articles within a journal. Various citation style guides mention magazine departments or article types. For example, Per Chicago 16: "14.202 MAGAZINE DEPARTMENTS. Titles of regular departments in a magazine are capitalized headline-style but not put in quotation marks." The National Library of Medicine Style Guide refers to an optional [http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK7282/#A32443 Article Type] that if present should appear in brackets after the article title. Likewise both the APA and MLA styles require that citations of [http://isites.harvard.edu/icb/icb.do?keyword=k70847&pageid=icb.page363226#a_icb_pagecontent763087_review reviews] and [http://isites.harvard.edu/icb/icb.do?keyword=k70847&pageid=icb.page363226#a_icb_pagecontent763087_letter letters to the editor] be designated as such after the title. ser:Boghog|Boghog (ser talk:Boghog|talk) 06:34, 7 March 2017 (UTC)

Carcinogenesis
Ok, so there's a recent paper at Cristian Tomasetti, Lu Li, Bert Vogelstein. "Stem cell divisions, somatic mutations, cancer etiology, and cancer prevention" Science 24 Mar 2017: Vol. 355, Issue 6331, pp. 1330-1334 OI|10.1126/science.aaf9011
It has lots of quick-reviews such as [https://medicalxpress.com/news/2017-03-cancer-mutations-due-random-dna.html New study finds that most cancer mutations are due to random DNA copying 'mistakes'] Medicalxpress
It essentially confirms the same authors' earlier work: Cristian Tomasetti, Bert Vogelstein. "Variation in cancer risk among tissues can be explained by the number of stem cell divisions" Science 02 Jan 2015 Vol. 347, Issue 6217, pp. 78-81 OI|10.1126/science.1260825
In essence, it's a detailed analysis to back up and quantify the apparently-obvious (at least to the lay reader) assertion that cell types which are very common and which divide often are more likely to mutate and become cancerous. The articles arcinogenesis, auses of cancer, and ancer seem to overlook this line of thought.
Would someone care to address this? ser:LeadSongDog|LeadSongDog ser talk:LeadSongDog#top|come howl! 21:04, 24 March 2017 (UTC)
Some editors tried to add some information about this last time, and (grossly oversimplifying), and they (we? I can't actually remember whether I was directly involved) were told that it violated the letter of MEDRS because it was "only" a primary source, and more incidentally, that we should censor this information on the grounds of public health, because people who are smoking/obese/sedentary/eating nothing but beer and pizza won't change their lifestyles if they were told (accurately) that "most" cancer can't be prevented through diet and exercise. I've got more sympathy for the former, although the latter is absolutely true: people, including me, are bad at statistics. On the practical-editing side, I doubt that attitudes among editors have changed, so I saw the paper and decided to not even bother trying to add anything about it myself. The leading storyline back then among researchers who were trying to believe this paper and that cancer can almost always be prevented ran like this: "Sure, it's a random mutation, but if you don't have the right diet, then you'll get more random mutations". Except, of course, that if the mutation is triggered (e.g., by alcoholic beverages), then it's not "random" in the sense that is used in this paper. Scientists are no less human than the rest of us, and it takes humans a while to drop their cherished old stories and consider a new one on its own merits. On the subject of the paper itself, I'm glad that this one included breast and prostate cancer, and given the results ‚Äì and the guilt that most cancer patients feel ‚Äì I hope that rostate cancer gets a big "This is not your fault and there was nothing you could do to prevent it, so stop feeling guilty already" slapped into the lead. Some day. We'll probably have to wait for multiple review articles to be published in top-quality journals first, though. ser:WhatamIdoing|WhatamIdoing (ser talk:WhatamIdoing|talk) 03:11, 25 March 2017 (UTC) From my understanding a significant portion can prevented and significant portion cannot. ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk ¬∑ pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs ¬∑ pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 06:37, 25 March 2017 (UTC) For me personally, the fun in this research is the variation. 95% of prostate cancer is non-preventable, but 66% of lung cancer is realistically preventable. (You "just" have to ban anything that makes people breathe smoke [including non-tobacco sources of smoke].) These studies have concluded that more than 90% of cancers are due to non-hereditary causes, and that less than half of those non-hereditary cancers are due to any factor within the control of the patient. ser:WhatamIdoing|WhatamIdoing (ser talk:WhatamIdoing|talk) 06:45, 25 March 2017 (UTC) Multiple mutations must occur before a cell becomes cancerous. Hence it is possible and perhaps even likely that environmental factors, random mutations, and heredity all contribute to a single malignant transformation. The arcinogenesis article at the moment has far bigger problems. The lead was enormous and far too detailed. I have split out a lot of the material from the lead into sections. The sections also need more work. Finally I have added a short mention of the random mutation hypothesis to the lead. This should also be discussed in more depth in the body of the article. ser:Boghog|Boghog (ser talk:Boghog|talk) 10:19, 25 March 2017 (UTC) lcohol and cancer#Genetic variation and cancer risk section needs better referencing(almost no sources[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Alcohol_and_cancer&diff=772117170&oldid=768611668]), as well as, ealth effects of tobacco#Cancer (at the end of first paragraph)....[https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/causes-prevention/risk/tobacco/second-hand-smoke-fact-sheet][https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3855285/]...(both are part of auses of cancer[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Causes_of_cancer&diff=772116633&oldid=769472502])--ser:Ozzie10aaaa|Ozzie10aaaa (ser talk:Ozzie10aaaa|talk) 12:22, 25 March 2017 (UTC) To expand a bit on Boghog's comment: Tomasetti's work is being misreported; it's two-thirds of mutations in cancerous cells that are random, not two-thirds of individual people with cancer. The numbers are similar (and multiple sources seem to agree that around 60% of cancer cases are non-preventable), but we should be precise when we're describing this work. ser:WhatamIdoing|WhatamIdoing (ser talk:WhatamIdoing|talk) 16:36, 26 March 2017 (UTC)

lear
Class of diseases; format of article? hakomatosis and ser:MKoehler/sandbox
So we right now have hakomatosis. A student group has decided to improve this article, and their draft is at ser:MKoehler/sandbox.
There are some obvious problems with sources and lack of inline citations, but I am asking a bigger question here - should the hakomatosis article basically be a brief overview with wikilinks to the actual diseases, or should it be expanded as the class plans to do, and treated like it, itself, is a disease or condition?
In my view this is bad meta-editing - the hakomatosis is unlikely to remain in sync with the subarticles, and little in the Phakomatosis article will be about anything.
I guess in my view if the Phakomatosis article were to be expanded, it should be done by a) updating each of the disease articles; b) adding citations to the lead of each disease article, and c) copying those leads to the main article. If there is anything that is specific to the class, that could go in a brief discussion of the class itself. That would be good meta-editing.
Thoughts? ser:Jytdog|Jytdog (ser talk:Jytdog|talk) 20:03, 27 March 2017 (UTC) As it is a broad group of conditions rather than a single condition better to keep it as it is rather than try to make it out like a single disease. What's on your mind?
LeadSongDog posted a paper just above that I thought was interesting. I've got a few things on my list in the medical-humanities line, especially [http://nymag.com/scienceofus/2017/03/these-are-the-most-prestigious-diseases.html this one] that ranks specialties and diseases by the amount of prestige that the medical profession accords them (and therefore everything from how well patients with various conditions are treated to how much specialists are paid).
I'm sure that some of you have interesting sources or ideas at the moment, and it's fun to hear about them. So please share: What's on your mind these days? ser:WhatamIdoing|WhatamIdoing (ser talk:WhatamIdoing|talk) 03:20, 25 March 2017 (UTC) [https://insiderlouisville.com/business/health-leaders-proposed-federal-budget-would-gut-medical-research/]--ser:Ozzie10aaaa|Ozzie10aaaa (ser talk:Ozzie10aaaa|talk) 17:25, 25 March 2017 (UTC) A ~20% cut would affect a lot of research. If you assume that the average work runs on a five-year grant cycle, it would pretty much mean that no new projects could be started next year. I don't expect it to work out that way, though. Some of the patient lobbies are just too strong for it. ser:WhatamIdoing|WhatamIdoing (ser talk:WhatamIdoing|talk) 16:24, 26 March 2017 (UTC) The NIH lead the efforts that turned HIV/AIDS from a death sentence to a chronic disease with near normal life expectancy. It being cut so significantly will definitely put human health at risk when the next big issue arises.ser:Doc James|Doc James (ser talk:Doc James|talk ¬∑ pecial:Contributions/Doc James|contribs ¬∑ pecial:EmailUser/Doc James|email) 08:11, 27 March 2017 (UTC) If the article is correct, they're talking 18% of 0.9%, or just 0.162% of the US federal budget. This smells more like a bargaining chip than a serious policy choice. ser:LeadSongDog|LeadSongDog ser talk:LeadSongDog#top|come howl! 19:10, 27 March 2017 (UTC) Anyone who has had NIH grants in the US, or otherwise worked in concert with the various NIH translational agencies know that the agencies are in trouble, not because of these threatened cuts, but because of poorly executed fiscal planning in the period when the NIH pungent was doubled over a 5 year period. The current situation in the US is that median age of a scientist receiving the R01 is now in the 40s, and (relatedly), in the molecular biosciences, that 3 and 4 serial postdoctoral appointments en route to first academic appointment‚Äîor worse, perpetual postdoctoral limbo‚Äîare increasingly the norm. Add to this now, that the eventual flattening of the growth rate after the doubling period, and the contraction in real terms that took place when the economy has taken hits‚Äîthese now impact an artificially enlarged pool of individuals needing funding. So, as critical to the amount expended, is how the system is shaped, to accommodate whatever expenditures are provided. I have some confidence in Collins, in that regard. Otherwise, anyone who has been both in pharma and academia can also tell you that things could be done better, and more cost-effectively, than they are, at universities, where the 20% you speak of is easily wasted each year. [In pharma, investment recovery is the department redistributing, refurbishing, reselling , or donating no longer used equipment that represents significant investment‚Äîdown to pieces as small as a rotary evaporator (<$5K). Investment recovery in academia is the hallway corridor, the tops of storage cabinets, and ultimately, the dumpster.] Small example, but as a process guy, I can tell you it gets no better‚Äîno more efficient or cost-effective‚Äîwhen discovery workflows are designed, i.e., how to get ADME-Tox data on a new small molecule, when no experience or expertise is present, no alliances/partnerships exist, and everyone's ego and funding residual is a stake in the game. Add the propensity for last minute decisions and efforts‚Äîwho has never been on an academic grant writing team that did not hit send on the very last day‚Äîand the matter of cost inefficiencies are all the clearer. Le Prof ser:Leprof 7272|Leprof 7272 (ser talk:Leprof 7272|talk) 08:30, 3 April 2017 (UTC)

More Wikidata funk - infobox gene
So I was just looking at our article on CNB1, where the emplate:infobox gene is deployed. The infobox had a disease associations with obesity, and also said this channel "interacts" with inoleic acid. (I have fixed that so you can't see it now)
I went to Wikidata and saw that the association with obesity was added by ProteinBoxBot [https://www.wikidata.org/w/index.php?title=Q18028136&type=revision&diff=466393145&oldid=459281559 here]. based on [http://chibi.ubc.ca/Gemma/phenotypes.html?phenotypeUrlId=DOID_9970&ncbiId=3745 this database]. If you look at that database, you will see that this protein was associated with obestity based on MID|23251661, a primary source (at least it is of a GWAS in humans) and that this gene has also been linked to ongenital diaphragmatic hernia based on a primary source in rats, MID|15088113.
At our article, I only see the infobox template and cannot see how to suppress these things. For some reason only the obesity thing was showing in Wikidata, but in any case I [https://www.wikidata.org/w/index.php?title=Q18028136&type=revision&diff=472377066&oldid=469269994 removed it]. Which may well upset some people there.
As for the lineoleic acid thing, that came from a different Wikidata entry altogether, and I [https://www.wikidata.org/w/index.php?title=Q21107884&type=revision&diff=472377160&oldid=439605508 removed it] from there, as this is just bizarre to have in a WP article. Linoleic acid is a common dietary acid and from where I sit drawing associations between stuff we eat and modulation of ion channels is just not good.
The infobox gene should not have health claims in it if they are coming from Wikidata, I think. Thoughts? ser:Jytdog|Jytdog (ser talk:Jytdog|talk) 01:26, 5 April 2017 (UTC) [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23251661?dopt=Abstract] using that as a source, means wikidata is still "dysfunctional",(am uncertain as to how to help "fix", generally speaking...maybe start here[https://www.wikidata.org/wiki/Wikidata_talk:WikiProject_Medicine])--ser:Ozzie10aaaa|Ozzie10aaaa (ser talk:Ozzie10aaaa|talk) 10:16, 5 April 2017 (UTC)

More Eyes Needed at epsis
A lot of recent activity at the epsis and eptic shock pages recently strongly advocating the addition of information about Dr. Marik's recently proposed IV thiamine/Vitamin C therapy for sepsis/septic shock. This is despite the lack of rigorous study and no mention yet (that I'm aware of) in secondary sources that meet P:MEDRS criteria (not even a recent robust RCT yet). Discussion here [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Sepsis#Norfolk_doctor_found_a_treatment_for_sepsis]. ser:TylerDurden8823|TylerDurden8823 (ser talk:TylerDurden8823|talk) 12:53, 3 April 2017 (UTC)
I'm not surprised, since it made a big splash in the news recently. The news reports that I saw indicated that a proper study was underway, which means that it was neither complete nor published (although, if the results are actually as good as he's claimed, he needs to be talking to his IRB about ending early on ethical grounds). Generally, with this sort of thing, it's more effective to mention the claims in a restrained, limited manner, rather than trying to excise them completely. A complete absence makes people think that editors merely haven't heart about it; a limited statement, perhaps along the lines of t|"In 2017, Edward Example claimed that outcomes could be dramatically improved by giving patients Vitamin C, thiamine, and some unspecified steroids; however, these claims have not been scientifically proven" helps people feel like their area of interest was included (and some of them will learn that "I got my name in the news!" is not the height of scientific evidence). Bonus points if you can find a way to link to cience by press release without anyone yelling at you. :-) ser:WhatamIdoing|WhatamIdoing (ser talk:WhatamIdoing|talk) 23:17, 3 April 2017 (UTC) Will look in, thanks for calling it to our attention, ing|TylerDurden8823. Last thing needed in this area is misinformation. In the spirit of no-publicity-bad-publicity, perhaps a mention of the story, as a story that has appeared, and the fact that it is not yet established medical science can appear, so people searching can find the WP article, and get some evidence-based information. Cheers. ser:Leprof 7272|Leprof 7272 (ser talk:Leprof 7272|talk) 01:04, 6 April 2017 (UTC) That seems reasonable to me as long as it's truly/properly qualified with the necessary caveats so the public is not misled. ser:TylerDurden8823|TylerDurden8823 (ser talk:TylerDurden8823|talk) 07:52, 6 April 2017 (UTC)

Best Regards, ser:Barbara (WVS)|Barbara (WVS)¬†ser talk:Barbara (WVS)|‚úê¬†pecial:Emailuser/Barbara (WVS)|‚úâ 12:27, 15 April 2017 (UTC) Different ip 64.85.216.31, same edits ser:Barbara (WVS)|Barbara (WVS)¬†ser talk:Barbara (WVS)|‚úê¬†pecial:Emailuser/Barbara (WVS)|‚úâ 13:04, 15 April 2017 (UTC)
It's the same user, of course, from Mountain Grove, MO. But dynamic IPs are not socks; they are just IPs that change each time the user logs on. It's important to realise that some editors simply prefer to edit as IPs and we should respect their choice. Some IP editors may be very experienced, and this one does appear to know what he's talking about, especially on the topic of categories. They ser talk:64.85.216.208|claim to have been editing for almost ten years and I can't see any reason not to AGF on that. If it's any help, there is guidance on best practice for categorisation at ikipedia:Categorization #Categorizing pages: "q|... each categorized page should be placed in all of the most specific categories to which it logically belongs. This means that if a page belongs to a Subcategorization|subcategory of C (or a subcategory of a subcategory of C, and so on) then it is not normally placed directly into C." there are exceptions, but they are only in very particular circumstances. In the case of erry Gibson, he belongs in Category:Negro league baseball players, but because that is a more specific sub-category of Category:Negro league baseball, he does not belong in that category. Similar considerations apply to several of the other categories the IP removed. Your best bet, if you think that exceptions are appropriate, is to raise the issue on the article talk page, which the IP claims to be monitoring, so you should be able to discuss the issue and, hopefully, reach an agreement that is best for the article. HTH --ser:RexxS|RexxS (ser talk:RexxS|talk) 13:44, 15 April 2017 (UTC) Thanks so much for your response, especially when many people are getting ready for the holidays.
